body.div1:
Honorable Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
Sir: I have the honor to inform the Department of any return May 12th to Basoko from the Lomami River. The following is a brief as count of the manner in which the Arab Slave dealers have been driven from this section of the Kongo Free State.
Upon my arrival at Basoko March2nd Commandant Chaltin informed me he had recieved orders from Inspector of the State, M. Five in the Sankuru River to proceed to Bena- Kamba, in the Lomami River and commence asperations
<pb facs="20170614_144014"
against the Arabs who were supposed to be at that place in large numbers, and if suc- cessful to proceed to Tchari 60 miles farther south occu- py that place, and these re- turn to Bena Kamba, and proceed to Riba-Riba. Nothing was said in This Communication which could be combined into an order to arrack any Arab pasts situated between Isanghi and Kibonge Com- mandant Chatlin invited me to accompany kim, as his guest, but I preferred first to see Stanley Falls under Arab rule, as I had an idea they would revolt in a few months.
I accepted the invitation to come on a Steamer leaving a few weeks after his departure. He left Basoko for Bena- Komba March 7th on board the Steamer "Ville d'anvers" with 200
<pb facs="20170614_144024"
200 Joediers + 2 Krupp 7.5 omm Canon.
The Steamer "Ville de Buxelles" was sent to Equator Station, 500 miles down river to being re-enforcements. I left for Stanley Falls march 4th and remained until March 17th when M.Jobback, The President, Kindly sent me to Basako in the pleau- "launch" A.I.A. in order to cash the "Bruxelles" on her return"
During my stay at the Falls I could see there was a strong feeling amongst the Arabs against the State, and that it only re- quired a very small thing to begin the war against the Govern- ment.
The Vali (or Governor) at the Falls Commonly known as Rachid, but whose real name is Rachid, but whose real name is Rachid. Ben. said Ben. Jama. Marajebe which means, Rachid, (Ben) son of said, (Ben) son of Jama Marajebe) and a nephew of Tippoo Tip was and a nephew of Tippo Tip was exceedingly discourtious to me
when
<pb facs="20170614_144031"
when he learned I intended going to the Lomani.
The position he held was a most expeditionary one; he was, by de- partment of the Governor of the Kongo Free State, by order of the auchoutioud in Brussels, Vali of Stanley Falls, and received by salary of six thousand Francs per anew ($1158.00); he was always furnished with the uniform of a Caplaui Commandant.
The reasons given for placing at the head of government at sanchan important points a man with so notorious a reputation, were, that he would be able to control all the arabs of this region and so prevent any concentrated attack against the State posts. As future events have proved the State were entirely wrong in their estimate of the Arab strength.
The State had a Resident here, M. Tobback, who conducted all
the
<pb facs="20170614_144039"
the affairs of Government and was Commandant of the Past containing 150 soldiers, situated on the right bank of the Kongo. (see map marked Exhibit "B").
Suppose the population at Stanley Falls might be put down at 5000, but it was the greatest Ivory market in Central Africa. While I was there the Agent of the Belgian Factory, purchased in 5 days four (4) tons, worth in Europe 25,000 Francs (or $4833.00). per ton J to say nothing of rubber. We sent down to Stanley Pool aboard the s.s. Archduchess Thiphanie". 18 tons Ivory and 29 tons rubber all the result of four months work.
Upon arrival at Basoko Sfound the "Brussels" not yet arrived, + was compelled to wait until the 25th when the cause in. On board were 150 soldiers and one Lieutenant and a Sergeant; Immediately the Carpentars were set to work and a thing farricade placed entirely aroused her, and on the 27th.
All
<pb facs="20170614_144048"
All being completed we left for Bena Kauba, having on board Leuit de Bock, Sergeant Lamers +myself. 150 soldiers, armed with Albini Rifers, 45,370 cartridges provisions for the officers and 10 tons of rice for the men...
Noching of note occurred, while as- cending the river until March 31st when the decapitated body of a woman was passed, floating down streams. No cause for this apparent murder could be found until that evening the steamer stopped at a large village which was in feawers. Two detach- ments of soldiers were immediately made ready to go ashore, as an Arab raid had evidently been made.
M. de roacks Joak one and I the other reach went to an end of the town and as my men started into the bush they received three shots from the dark- ness of the forest; we charged the pre- firing three valleys white on the rest but could see nothing as might had
fallen.
<pb facs="20170614_144056"
fallen, so returned to the steamer. On the way back found eight bodies of women and children, all headless and some with their legs and arms gone. Mr. de Bock found in the Banana plantation two children and an old woman, who, after some hours, were persuaded to let us what had occurred.
It seems the village had been attacked by a party of Arab slave hunters about 3 o'clock that afternoon. They had captured over a hundred of the in habi- tants, and were engaged in des- troying the Joen when the steamer came in sight. They retreated im mediately, and the shots I received were probably fired by the rear guard.
The next morning we followed their rail some 3 or 4 miles back found the bodies of 20 persons men, women + children, who were too young, old or inform to march rapidly, so
had
<pb facs="20170614_144103"
had been murdered in order to allow the caraven to retreat as fast as possible.
As we had orders to proceed with all despatch and join Com- mandant Chaltin at Bena. Kamba M. de Bocko did not consider him- self justified in pursuing farther the enemy.
Such seems as this village pre- sented were afterwards of not unfre- quent occurence.
April 10th another body was passed, but no xause for teach could be discovered.
The Steamer arrived at Bema- Kamba the next day, and instead of finding a great number of Arabs, who were supposed to be fortfied here, nothing was to be seen but the ruins of the Past established by the State some years ago. This place was occupied lasy years ago. This place was occupied last year as the Headquarters of the Company known as the "Kalanga Lyndicate, of which
Mr
<pb facs="20170614_144110"
Mr. Hodistin was the chief, and was destroyed by the Arabs at the same time they murdered him and his Expedition while on the way to Riba-Riba.
Here we found letters directing the steamers to come to Lhome, 20 miles farther up. We left immediately and after a day and a half arrived the S.S. Villa d'anvers" was here, + the Captain gave us Commandant Chaltins orders to march without delay to Tchain + join him.
We left the next morning, + that afternoon encountered the Commandant returning. He had been most-success- ful defeating the Arabs m an open fight, and completely destroying the town of Jchari, which consisted of 1200 houses and 15000 people two days later both steamers after for Bena Kamba, where the Expedition was to be re-organized for its March to Riba-Riba, through a section of country said to be defeuded
by
<pb facs="20170614_144123"
by a coting body of arabs.
Small pay had appeared amongst the soldiers and porters one white officer, Mr. Coppee also had it. The Surgeon Dr. Dupont had a bad case of dysentery, so, as the "Villa d' Anvers" was leaving for Basko in a few days it was decided to send these two offices back.
March 21st we left Bena Kamba for Riba-Riba-505 strong district whe'd formed into columns as follows Cost. Vanguard Lequeant Nachan 66,soldiers Cannon. M. Mohen. 6. -44 Carriers for Canon- Commandant Chaltin 14" Co. "B" Caprain Marek. 75" Luggage Provisions Lentove So Carriers for Luggage etc. Co. "C"- Lieutenant De Bock. 90" Co. "II"- Rear Geard, Leutenat James. 31." Total Soldiers= 282 Porters, Servants Bayo= 178 Prisoners-Arab (used as) 45 Porters)= Total= 505
<pb facs="20170614_144218"
As the men were armed with the albini Rifle and carried 100 cartridges. Besides this ammunition 40 boxes, each containing 160 cartridges were distributed, this brought our ammunintion supply up to 34,600 cartridges.
Fifty men of at Company "B" each carried a shell or canister shot for the Cannon, and for the carriages of the piece I distrubted the Porters as follows: 12 men for cannon, weight 230 lbs in 3 details. 12 men for the carriage weight 240 lbs in 3 details. 4 men for 2 wheels, weight 50lbs each 6 men for 3 caissons, weight 40lbs. each containing 65 charges powder. The luggage consisted of 3 double Edington Tento six caup beds, 3 canteens, containing, cooking apparatus, pates, knives, forks etc. One trunk and bedding for each to buy provisions on the road, and 11 "chap boxes"
